div.l: Or ellis he is a fool as Clerkys seyn
Our manciple / y hope he wolbe ded
Swa warkys ay / the wanges in his hed
And therfor y am come / and eek Aleyn
To grynde our corne / and cary it ham a gayn
I pray you spede vs hens / yf that ye may
It shalbe do ꝙquod symkyn / bi my fay
What wol ye don / whil it is on honde
Bi god / ryht be the hoper wol y stonde
Qudd Aleyn / and se how the corne gas In
Iit saw y nevir by my fadir kyn
How that the hoper wagges / twa and fra
Aleyn answerde / Iohn wylt thou swa
Thanne wol y be bineth / bi my crowne
And se how the mele / falles a downe
In to the trouh / that shal be my disport
For In fayth / y may ben oon of your sort
I am as ille a myller / as ye
This myller smyled / at her nycete
And thouht al this is do / but for a wyle
They wene that no man / may hem bigyle
But bi my thryft / yit shal y blere her eye
For al the sleyhte / in her philosophie
The more queynt knakkes / that they make
The more wol y stele / whan that y take
In stede of flour / yit wol y yef hem brenne
The grettest clerkes / be nat wysest men
As whilom to the wolf / thus spake the mar͗e
Of al her hert / ne coıı̄unte y nat a tare
Out of the dore / he goth ful pryvyly
Whanne that he sawe his tyme softely
